reviewText:
In my humble opinion, this is the greatest ARPG ever created, enhanced by the fantastic mod support that the community has used to the fullest. The class system is amazing, allowing you to combine two out of nine mastery trees to make your own unique class with an incredible amount of customization.  You have the fully offensive, close-quarter mastery Warfare, which revolves around duel weidling weapons and becoming a whirlwind of AoE and single target damage, at the cost of defence. Ranged masteries like Hunting which allows you to deal huge amounts of damage from a distance, and debuff your enemies defences. Magic masteries such as Spirit, which allows you to drain the life from your enemies! And 6 other unique and exiting masteries.

The world is vibrant and beautiful, starting in Greece, them moving to Egypt, then China, and with the DLC, even into the domain of Hades himself! The quests while perhaps a little generic, are very fun and easy to follow, and often give satisfying rewards along with a nice chunk of EXP and Gold! Not to mention the amazing loot you will find along your journey.

All in all it is a wonderful game, one of my all time favourites, I highly reccomend checking it out. And if you enjoy it, keep an eye on Grim Dawn, a game being developed by many of the same people that made Titan Quest, it promises to be an equaly enchanting ARPG set in the Victorian times!

Titan Quest, and its worthy expansion Immortal Throne is, imo, part of the holy trinity in ARPG's along side Diablo and Dungeon Siege. Titan Quests theme is unique, and the gameplay is so faithful to the principles that made diablo so great.
There is a massive, diverse world covered in several acts. In combination with tons of loot in the suspected qualities to keep the flow of the game intact. On top of that, the game also follows the model of increased difficulty (normal, epic, legendary), remeniscent of Diablo's normal, nightmare and hell. Each difficulty features harder monsters and better loot.

If at one point, you would get tired of the original campaign, you can try some of the fantastic mods available, especially Lilith: Battle for Jalavin (a totally newly created world which will take you up to 20 hours to complete). This mod in combination with other well known TQ mods such as Masteries mod (skill overhaul mod), gives more than enough incentive to go through the whole experience all over again with a fresh new slate.

All in all, if you are a fan of ARPG's it is a genuine crime not to have this masterpiece. The majority of the now-closed TQ studio (Iron Lore) are in the process of making a spiritual succesor named Grim Dawn (by Crate Entertainement). Given their history with TQ, this is a title to keep in mind as well and currently available through early acces on steam.

Closing advice: go spend money on this, preferably as soon as possible, you will not regret it.

reviewText:
Titan Quest is a refreshing experience after Diablo 3. Make no mistake: I liked Diablo 3 a lot but it was certainly a bit too casual for my taste. Titan Quest brings back the good old skill tree concept. There are no races here - you just pick the skill tree at the beginning and after several level-ups you can pick another one (the game refers to these as masteries) and as a result of this combination you will have a class.

I'll give you an example: you want to be the expert of close-combat, an expert of swords and other melee weapons. You pick the mastery called Warfare for this purpose. At the same time you would like to summon spirits to aid you in combat and throw molten rocks at your enemies or utilise other earth magic spells. You pick Earth and there you go you have just become a Battle Mage. Overall, you have 9 masteries so you can guess how many combinations you can have. This gives us quite a high replayability value.

Other than this the formula is pretty much the same as in Diablo:
--the story is divided up into various Acts which all end in a boss battle
--you have places full of enemies but you can rest in towns; these give you opportunity to pick up quests and visit vendors for purchasing / selling items you acquired by looting
--you kill then you loot: rinse and repeat!
--you level up and spend points on your main attributes and skills points on your skills offered by the masteries you picked
--you get to loot many items and weapons' strength is indicated by their colour; you have legendary and set items here and you can further enhance your weapons by inserting charms and relics into them
--while you are getting stronger you are expected to find items that add to your elemental protection

One of the criticism regarding Titan Quest was that it was too similar to Diablo. But if you have a decent system that works quite well why is it an issue to have it copied? The creators simply thought these were quite good in Diablo so they only changed the skill variety which I believe is commendable.

Also, the environment is a bit different as the game takes place in ancient Greek so you can expect monsters from that mythology. Act 4 is simply jaw-dropping with its River Styx and the City of Lost Souls.

The game was released back in 2006 and its expansion pack a year later. Still, the game looks good and it utilises Havok physics quite well. One interesting thing, though: the game does not generate a new environment once you restart it, not like in Diablo. So, should you replay it with another class or on another difficulty (these get unlocked after game completion - again, a similarity with Diablo) all environments will look similar.

I liked Titan Quest. I played it after Diablo 3 and for me it was refreshing. I liked its environments with all the mythological creatures. With the 4 Acts you have at least 40-50 hours for one walkthrough on normal difficulty. I say that's quite long considering the high replayability and the multiplayer option available.

reviewText:
Titan Quest Gold Review   (TQ+TQ:IT)

This is one amazing ARPG. I first played it when Titan Quest came out in 2006 (Titan Quest: Immortal Throne is simply the expansion which came out in 2007) and ended up spending hundreds, maybe thousands of hours playing it - there is simply something special about it.

The negative:

The game has some bugs that were never fixed (as Iron Lore ended up closing down before any major patches were released) but it's nothing game breaking. In addition, we're expexting some patches to come through from Nordic games in the near future.

Another aspect that is worth noting is the fact that this game has no randomization (though it didn't stop me from spending a BIG portion of my time playing it).

The positive:

First of all, the game takes place in an alternative ancient world - the devs decided to take myths and legends from all over the world and use them as a base for the game's story and the result is astounding. Not only is the story very interesting but devs and the the voice actors did an amzing job presenting it to the player.

In addition to the enthralling story the game offers a total of 9 masteries of which you get to combine 2 in order to create a unique build to suit your personal play style (You can choose your second mastery after level 8).

Another major aspect of the game that is worth mentioning is the environments - let's just say that they are breathtaking. You can really see all the hard work that went into making this game.

Last but not least, the game is long. I'm currently replaying it and at 10+ hours I haven't even gotten through Act I, and there's a total of 4 Acts + 3 difficulties!!! It's bound to keep you playing for a long time.

The conclusion:

All in all, this game has a lot to offer to those who are willing to spend some time with it. Sure, it has some bugs, but what game doesn't? And unlike most games, it offers a very solid story combined with great audio and visual effects as well as a rather unique skill system.
I would recommend this game to any fan of the ARPG genre. It's not too late to try it out!

Welcome to the Exciting World of Hack N Slash RPGs

Titan Quest distills the diablo formula into a very refined and polished experience. Many will equate Titan Quest as a diablo clone, this is only one viewpoint. I felt that Titan Quest used the design philosophy of if it’s not broke don’t fix it, to the hack n slash genre. I only wish Blizzard would have approached diablo 3 in the same manner.

In titan quest players embark on a mythological quest to fell the fearsome titans. All the while collecting valuable loot on the way, which I must say is very addicting. The point and click gameplay is assessable to newcomers and veterans alike. There is also different play styles based on the different classes and class combinations in the game. This adds to the depth and replay-ability once you’ve completed the main story once.

I would be remised if I didn’t touch on the soundtrack. Iron Lore produced a visually striking game for its time, but it accompanied by an outstanding soundtrack.  I highly recommend checking out the soundtrack, which unfortunately isn’t something I can do often.

One thing of note, it is strongly recommended to get the unofficial patch of the game. This fixes a number of bugs and balance issues with power sets. Unfortunately the developer had to halt patches and expansions for this game. As such the community has picked up the torch and ran with it. This speaks something about the game in its self. Not many new IPs develop a following that works to improve the game even when the developer can no longer.

Overall I strongly recommend this to any diablo fans who have not checked it out, or any who didn’t quite like Diablo 3.

This review covers v1.20 beta official patch.

Titan Quest is another isometric top down ARPG and it's a damn good one at that.  Immmortal Throne is the expansion to Titan Quest and adds graphical updates, another equipable gear slot, more quests and another ACT making it 4 ACTs in total.

If you like games like Diablo, Torchlight and Grim Dawn this is a must play through.  There are 3 different difficulties to this game.  Normal, Epic and Legendary.  You start out in Normal and once you beat ACT IV's final boss you can unlock Epic and so forth.  This game can be difficult on normal especially if you haven't planned ahead with a build in mind.  The 1st two ACTs are fairly easy, but once you reach ACT III the difficulty does start to ramp up and you may need to respec.

The following site allows you to configure a build:

http://www.titancalc.com/

You can respec once you reach certain major cities in the game.  Once you've activated the portals to towns you can go back at any time.  Respeccing your class costs gold and you can respec your skills you've chosen, but you can not respec the mastery.

Mastery's are the specific class you want to be.  IE:  mage or tank class.  Skills are IE: a heal or dual wielding swords.

You can enchant your gear in the game too by finding parts of relics and charms while out in the wild killing monsters.  Collect enough and you can make a complete piece and then enchant your gear.  You can farm areas in the game and you can farm bosses too.

You don't need to install the fan patch any longer due to its current developers updating the game, but by doing so may break older MODs.  Most, if not all, of the fan patch has been implemented and fixes most known issues.  Online multiplayer works as well, but you will need to register with your email in order to play it.  Hopefully this will be patched out on launch of the official re-release so we can just use Steam instead.

Nordic games have bought out the rights to this game and have been updating it and have been doing a fantastic job.  Hopefully they will continue to do so to make this game more compatible with current PC's so more people can enjoy it.  Great game and extremely worth your while!!!  10/10

Note:  Titan Quest has been abandoned and as such you SHOULD play Immortal Throne instead!

“Judge if you want, we are all going to die. I intend to deserve it.”

Titan Quest is a great and very enjoyable hack & slash game with plenty of classes and skills. The voice acting, sound effects and music are all well done. It is rounded out by proficiently designed environments, with a lot of attention to detail and extensive references to the ancient mythologies of Greece, Egypt, Orient and China.

The add-on, in form of Immortal Throne, succeeds in expanding the mythical world of Titan Quest by continuing the story across the dark and more sinister Underworld of Hades. Furthermore it introduces a couple of new weapons, and one additional skill class for the original game. It is a textbook case of a great expansion.

The only shortcoming is the total lack of level randomization, making the game very linear on each of the three difficulties. But it compensates this disadvantage with better loot and a few unique monster challenges.

reviewText:
With Diablo 3 still a year away, Titan Quest remains the pinnacle of the Adventure-RPG game category. It's a hefty and challenging ARPG, with a deep and rewarding class/skill system. The graphics are realistic and attractive, and the GUI is the most polished of any ARPG to date.

Gameplay is 70-100 hours, depending on which character class you play. The quest is long, and it tells a great story.

One word of caution. Seek out and install fan patch 1.17a (or greater). It fixes a technical glitch in the Immortal Throne chapters that creates a runaway CPU problem on modern computers. It's at a critical point in the game, and can't be ignored. As I understand it, the developers were terminated shortly after the Expansion was released, which means there was no official bug patch. Fortunately, the fan patch exists to clean up this and a few other issues related to character skills. It is an excellent patch, and 100% compatible with the Steam version of this game.

reviewText:
The easiest way to describe this game is think of Diablo II, but imagine a much better looking environment (in terms of both graphics and ambience) and set to Greek, Egyptian and Asian mythology.

The gameplay is nearly identical to that of Diablo II (i.e. click the button to hack and slash, pick up items, sell loot, etc) with some minor changes.  Health and energy regenerate slowly over time and weapon/armor enhancements can be removed.

Primary and secondary professions also make the game somewhat different.  The skill system is complex, but you can undo previous choices.

The environment is especially good.  The outside areas feel alive, with seagulls flying overhead in coastal towns and dogs wagging their tails near their owners.  Leaves, grass and flowers even sway in the breeze.

Like Diablo II, Titan Quest is boring in single player mode.  It can accomodate several players in one server and the entire campaign is multiplayer/co-op.

reviewText:
Originally posted on March 7, 2009

Titan Quest Gold (both the base game and Immortal Throne), is an action RPG in the top down mouse heavy diablo tradition. However, is very much a game of this decade, featuring real time day and night cycles, advanced lighting, great animations, and ragdoll physics. In that sense, Titan Quest's gameplay feels like it's from another era, but it's engine feels very up to date. This can make a for a very engaging experience if you're looking for an old school action RPG to get addicted to for a while. The game looks great, sounds great, and packs in hours of gameplay and fun, as it features three levels of difficulty meant to be unlocked and played in order to get even better loot, and online play which is very fun if you have friends playing the game with you on skype and whatnot. All of this set in ancient greek times to accurate mythology (for the most part).

That being said, the gameplay is incredibly repetitive, none of the characters are at all memorable, and certain game mechanics simply feel counter intuitive. For example, the randomized loot system is fun, but i really don't want to spend 50 hours completing a suit of armor which by that point is utterly useless. The game demands a massive time requirement which I am not always willing to yield. Also, the system of collecting relic shards to enchant armor and the inability to enchant rare armor (which is usually the best) is very frustrating.

Overall I would recommend this game to fans of action rpgs, but fans of different types of RPGs (The Elder Scrolls) or shooters and RTS' may find this game tough to get into.

reviewText:
Titan Quest Immortal throne is about as basic as an expansion can get. It adds some new quests, some new classes, some new monsters and ups the level cap. And that's about it. You have to pay close attention to even realize you are playing the expansion and not the main game.

Something to strongly keep in mind is that this expansion takes place after the original campaign, meaning that if you don't happen to have a save game ready where you have beaten the campaign then you'll have to do that before you can access the new content. Not exactly a good way to entice newcomers to the franchise.

The new class, or Mastery as it's called in the game is pretty much the same as the other masteries. Some damage abilities, some damage boosting abilities. Nothing really to care about and nothing that will really have that great of an impact on your game.

A number of convenience have found their way into the game as well, powerful spell scrolls that let you bypass a little grind and Caravans, or banks as the rest of us call them, that lets you store and access items across the various maps. Both are nice additions but not exactly big enough that they'd warrant an complete expansion pack.

Then there are the artefact's. The new uber weapons of Immortal Throne that require you to find a number of crafting items as well as a recipe in order to access their power. A nice addition but unfortunately because of their rarity they only really come into play in the late late game, when you are just grinding to max level and equipment.

All in all Immortal Throne is what I'd called a standard expansion pack. It adds a little there, improves a little here but does nothing really out of the ordinary and like some of similar expansion packs you probably won't even notice whether it's there or not.

Amazing game. Pulled off an original take on the Hack 'n' Slash genre. Similar to Diablo in a few ways, but they definitely pulled the class development and items in a new and different direction. I've literally spent hundreds of hours on my dozen varied characters and haven't gotten tired of the combinations yet!

The class system uses a unique system that lets you choose two separate classes from a list of eight. This essentially allows you to create over 25 unique character types. Not only that, but how you choose to develop those classes you choose will greatly impact how you play the game. Even for a one-character playthrough, if you actually complete every quest and side-mission, there is probably about 40 hours of solid gameplay! Not to mention, as many other dungeon crawlers have done before, there are three separate playthroughs of varying difficulty with new items and monsters.

There are a few cons however. The game was never fully completed before release, and fan-made patches are required to make some of the in-game elements work properly (i.e.: time-delay effects and such are broken). I actually was to level 25 with a character who was speializing in time mechanics before I realized that the effects weren't working.

Additionally, the game can sometimes be buggy. The physics work very well most of the time, and there's nothing more fun than power-hitting a weak enemy and watching the hilarious ragdoll physics ensue. However, sometimes these glitches can be funny, and sometimes they make you have to restart the level. The good news is that in over 400 hours of gameplay, I've only had to restart once due to an error.

Lastly, some character builds just don't pan-out and you have to reinvest your skill points elsewhere. I had this happen with a minion-based character, and I had this happen with an elemental melee-attack character.

Overall, I highly recommend this game for the fun co-op you can have, the fact that it's built differently than Diablo II but is just as much fun, and the classic Greek mythology involved in the plot!

Titan Quest is one of those hidden jewels that was released in 2006 and followed with an expansion in 2007. The game was developed by Iron Lore, a company that changed its name later to Crate Entertainment and released the popular Grim Dawn.

One of the most obvious features you will notice in the game is the Diablo-esque feeling from the beginning until the end. The game is essentially a hack and slash in a mythological world focused on the usual ‘’Defeat the great evil’’ throughout a couple of interesting locations such as Greece, Egypt, China and even Mount Olympus. The attention to details is striking and the game succeeds quite well at keeping you hooked up for hours. The game succeeds even further into showing details based on the enemies you kill which take form of the mythological creatures in every world, such as satyrs and cyclops in Greece or scorpions and alligator warriors in Egypt.

The customization menu at the menu is pretty simplistic, the options being the Character’s name, the gender and the tunic color, but where the game really shines is the skills customization in the game. Once you hit level 2, you have option to pick out of the skill trees available in game where you can choose the skills you would like to invest in. The beauty of the game is in the ability to pick a second tree at level 10 which enables you to pick a second tree and cross-breed abilities in order to make fantastic combos. I personally played a Soothsayer, a combination of Nature and Spirit focused on summoning pets and walking around with two wolves, a dryad and a lich king destroying my opponents. The customization in-game goes even further when you realize that many times you can combine runes that drop from monsters to make powerful enchants to add to your armor. To push the customization even further, the game has recipes where you can combine three specific enchanting items to make an even stronger one.

The game’s difficulty depends on the player’s choice on the skills taken which of course makes the game easier or harder but it also depends on the difficulty level or the specific area of the game which the player is experiencing. For instance, my summoner was doing well at 2-15, and it became weaker and weaker until level 20 and then started getting a bit better in terms of the survival of the pets.

The game’s massive amount of skills gives the game a ton of replayability if you can handle the hack and slash nature of the game (it is definitely not a game for everyone). The length of the game is quite big as well, I am only in chapter two after spending about 10 hours in game and there are at least a couple more chapters, which makes the game much longer than diablo 2 was. The sound of the game is amazing and manages to capture the area in the game, for instance while being in Greece you hear the usual war-like sounds and while being in Egypt there is the thematic Egyptian music which makes the game even more enjoyable.

If you are willing to put time into the steam workshop, you will also find a lot of mods for Titan quest, such as Underlord that make the game 10x as better and will offer you even more hours to spend on the game.

I did encounter a couple of tiny issues as well. For instance, every time you teleport the framerate drop considerably to 9. In the same time, my summons sometimes had a buggy pathing where they would get stuck in a specific fence and sometimes would switch from aggressive mode into passive. Some steam users also reported some issues into making the game work on the newer computers (the game is 10 years old after all).

Overall, I would say that for such an ancient game, the developers achieved an amazing job and I would definitely recommend this game to any hack and slash fan (extra points if you are a Greek mythology fan such as myself). Despise all its issues, Titan quest is an excellent game to enjoy and is worth every penny.

One of the most important things to have in a good RPG is replay value. Titan Quest is unique in that it has one of the best replay values I have found in a game. Titan Quest: Immortal Throne expounds upon that and gives you and even longer game, with more levels, items, and even another class which further increases the myriad of combinations of classes that you can play as.

The gameplay itself is very well done and I find the graphics beautiful. There are plenty of suprises that keep it interesting during the first playthrough. There are also a large amount of items ranging from rusty pieces of metal to legendary weapons that make you feel like a god while killing gods. You may think that because the maps never fluctuate on the next playthroughs that it would get old, but the developers thought of that too. They add seemingly impossibly hard bosses to keep the game interesting. Even if you find that it isn't, you can always start a new game and try a new combination of classes for a completely different gaming Experience.

Personalmente, amo este juego, por las horas de diversión que tuve con él cuando era chico, y que aun a mis 17 años sigo teniendo, porque la historia es muy buena, y principalmente, por haber sido el juego que me introdujo a la mitología griega, y por el que terminé devorando varios libros de esta (Figuradamente), y habiendo leido de dicho tema, el juego, salvo en algunos aspectos, es extremadamente fiel a ella, pero bueno.

Revised rating 0 / 10






Titan Quest Gold is one of those games I keep coming back to ... there is so much flexibility in the skill tree that allows re-playing to have a different feel based on class and skill choices.

Game graphics was state of the art at the time of the game's release, and still is pretty decent even by today's standards.  The base game (Titan Quest 2006) supports up to 1600x1200, and the expansion (Immortal Throne 2007) adds support for 1920x1080 resolution.  Animation and textures are really well implemented.  The grass waves as your character runs through it, and your character even leaves footprints in desert sands or ripples when running through water areas.

Voice acting is adequate, but the player will still be reading many chat bubbles.  There are some well researched ♥♥♥-bits of mythology and lore randomly seeded via non-core NPC characters which all add to the level of immersion and provide a contextual framework.

Re-spawn points are well placed on the whole.  The game feels open-world, but actually just has really wide lanes and a linear progression with several paths and side-quest areas.  Items are fairly well balanced, but the game is definitely kinder to aggressive melee than it is to other ability choices.  Playing as a caster or ranged requires more planning and tactical play, which provides a greater level of challenge and more of a sense of accomplishment.

The game runs really well in both single player and multi-player on current gen equipment (2013/14) under Windows 7 with up-to-date drivers.  At the time of writing this review Titan Quest does not appear to be supported under Windows 8 or Windows 8.1 for Multi-player.  The game appears to scale well when more performance hardware is thrown at it, but will run well enough on Windows XP on legacy hardware as this is what I had when the game first launched.

It's hard to put my finger on what makes me not recommend Titan Quest. Two things make it very difficult for me to even complete the game: (1) Too many passives abilities vs active abilities make you feel less in control of the combat, (2) Potions have no cooldown, so the only strategy you need to employ is having enough potions for any given fight.

Because of that the combat feels bland and repetitive from quite an early point in the game, and I just can't be bothered to finish it.

On the plus side, the graphics are quite good. Combat feels nice and responsive, especially with the weight added by the physics engine. The story is okay, with decent voice acting. The skill trees are interesting, especially as you can combine any two core classes.

I'm looking forward to Grim Dawn, the spiritual successor to Titan Quest from the same developers. Hopefully, that game will deliver where Titan Quest does not.

After hearing about how good this game was, I decided to pick it up when it was on sale. After 40 hours and finally finishing the entire game (aside from a few sidequests, I got too annoyed to finish them all), I felt overall disappointed. Why? Well let's find out.

~~~Pros~~~
+Everything looks nice. I normally don't judge a game by graphics, but everything just seems to be modeled to look really detailed and articulated. It just stands out to me in this game in comparison to other games.

+Setting. Greek mythology is awesome and always has lots of potential. Even a cyclops makes an appearance early on.

+Character customization options. 9 various masteries and you can pick two of them. Definitely creates some unique builds and promotes experimentation.

~~~Cons~~~
-It's incredibly slow in every way whatsoever. As I said before, it took me 40 hours to finish this game, and I feel they could've cut maybe half of that out because all you're doing for most of the game is running between boring locations. Had they made more interesting locations or maybe more sidequests, it wouldn't be so bad. But no. It just feels like unnecessary and unrewarding padding. Occasionally you'll find a cave, but it's not enough to fully reward exploration. Its lengthiness could prevent but the most devoted players to the experimentation of multiple classes either.

-Frustrating difficulty. Yes I know Diablo 1 & 2 had its annoying difficulty moments as well, but this game takes it beyond that. I died over 150 times finishing this game on normal difficulty! (maybe I just suck at it, eh who knows?) Though this game does have the benefit of not losing all your equipped gear when you die at least...

-Loot isn't too exciting. From the last couple of bosses I fought, the most interesting loot I got was an arcane formula. Most of the rest of the loot was stuff I could find from any old monster or even the shop. Maybe I had bad luck, but in other H&S games I played, the bosses would drop at least one worthwhile thing every time.


I understand that there's mods out there for this game and that higher difficulties add better enemies and loot, but I only find it fair to judge the core game, and I don't feel my time would be worth trying the higher difficulties. It has its place for those who want another hack and slash fix, but it's not for me.

Titan Quest is the single greatest ARPG of all time, second only to Diablo 2; it's also woefully neglected. You can expect to put in 40+ hours to complete a single playthrough, during which you'll cut a swathe through Greece, Egypt, the Orient, Olympus, and Hades, pitted against a menagerie of mythological beings that are familiar, yet refreshingly original. The graphics are better than virtually any ARPG on the market (no mean feat for a game that came out in 2006), and the mechanics are rock-solid, allowing you to synthesize two masteries to create any class you can think of. The atmosphere is rich and you can make the experience as subversive as you want: there are philosophers and scholars who will regale you with anecdotes and little pearls of wisdom; side-qeusts are in abundance, allowing for little reprieves during your journey; the loot-whoring is without equal; gargantuan boss fights like those in ARPGs of yore will punctuate every act on your road to Hades; the list, quite literally, goes on and on. You can usually pick Titan Quest Gold up for a meager $5 during any of the annual Steam sales, and you will be remiss if you neglect to do so.

When you first level up is where everything begins: you pick your class and you build it up instead of having presets. The interesting part afterwards is that you get to chose a second class some levels afterwards in order for your character to be more unique. You could, for example build a fire Mage with Warrior skills too. You have 3 difficulty settings that you unlock throughout your playthroughs, and you get to keep your weapons and items, but you lose some resistances, so building those up from the start is a must. You also get relics from defeated enemies that you can use on your items to boost your equipment, which is very similar to what Diablo has with Gems.\n\nI recommend this game to anyone who loves Diablo-type games. Titan Quest: Immortal Throne is an expansion to the 2006 action RPG Titan Quest developed by Iron Lore Entertainment. Immortal Throne is a single player and multiplayer game taking place in a fantasy world based on Greek / Egyptian / Oriental mythology.

If you are thinking of getting this game, make sure you get the Gold Edition, which includes both Titan Quest and Immortal Throne. Remember to install both games, but launch Immortal Throne only as it includes the original Titan Quest story campaign with lots of gameplay improvements. You will need the original Titan Quest in order to get Immortal Throne to work.

For a game released in 2006, im surprised that the graphics still hold out quite well in 2013. The environment art in particular still looks lush and crisp and doesn't lose out to the more recently released Diablo 3. I especially liked how there are no loading screen when i transition from the overworld to a cave / dungeon. It just looked very smooth and natural. Character customization options are very limited however, and you can only choose your gender and the colour of your tunic. More options to change hairstyles or skin colour would have been very welcome here.

The main story campaign is rather lengthy and it took me about 30 hours to finish all 4 story acts and that is considering I had skipped some side quests. There are harder difficulties to unlock and if you are dedicated enough, it can easily go up to 100s of hours.

Gameplay wise, being an Action RPG, it follows closely to the standard hack and slash action RPG style pioneered by the Diablo series. Unlike Diablo however, it has 9 different unique skill trees each with its own flavour, and you can mix and match any 2 of them that complements your playstyle. Wanna play a full on brutish warrior tank? A pure glass cannon caster? A hybrid of both? A necromancer rogue? You make the choice. There are alot of combinations of playstyle available.

Music is competently done, and sounds appropriate when played in the respective areas, gives the game world a little more flavour. Sound effects are also appropriately meaty with every swoosh of a blade and blast of a magic spell. Voice over work for the NPCs are a little forced and overacted but nothing too jarring.

Now as for the downsides, the backstory of the game is unremarkable and boring. I never really paid attention to the story and quest givers as it just feels like another excuse to get you kill more mobs. Early game can also feel abit tedious when you keep seeing the same mobs over and over again. It does get better at the later acts, where you get to see more interesting mob varieties.

The game can be very grindy and I felt that character progression can be abit too slow at times. Because this game released back in 2006, it lacks the bells and whistles of modern Action RPGs, such as needing to manually pick up gold, do item tetris in your inventory, and no hirelings to help sell items.

There is a Co-op mode, but unfortunately it didn't work well at all when I tried to co-op with a friend, as we encountered bugs when trying to synch up our questlines. It sometimes doesn't even recognize that we have completed the quest. Do not get this game if you are thinking of co-op. There are some temporary solutions available, but we figured it wasn't worth the hassle and would be complete wasted trip if the game decides to screw up at the later acts if we continue to co-op.

Overall Rating: 7.0 / 10

Graphics:  This game is a semi-older product so one wouldn't expect it to be impressive by today's standard, but the resources used for mapping and the enemy designs can only be summed up with the term 'lazy', the map is fairly large for a Diablo-esque game with many regions per chapter, with that being said the biome for a lot of these regions can feel slightly copy and paste, more so with the regions ranging from one of two types  'cave-tomb' you'll run through many of these and at times this can feel tedious, so this area of the game gets a solid five out of me for the fact that it has many variations from attacks, armor, weapons, enchantments, but the constant rehash and sometimes just total lack of variety keeps this from being a 7.


Sound:  The sound quality in this game is nothing to brag about, your basic attack makes sort of a monotone thud no matter what it is you're hitting, or what kind of weapon you're using, the only variations to this sound is when you're casting magic and even those can be slightly lack luster, even more annoyingly the death cries that monsters make can be teeth grindingly bad as killing large mobs of them can spam you with the same phrase over and over.

That being said however, the music can be complimenting at times while traversing long plains to get from point A to point B, because you died without finding the teleporter first between two possible regions, the voice acting for AI is also in that state of 'it's so bad that it's actually funny' category, ranging from ridiculous accents to voice pitches that one wouldn't normally use, for this mix of good and bad i'd have to leave this at a solid 6.


Gameplay:  This is where the game starts to shine, it has the loot is key formula rocking about it, though in my experience rare loot has been slightly easy to come by, I know this will not always be the case with every character I use and sometimes can be extremely hard to find going hours on end without seeing a single blue or green in the early stages.

The class system works a bit like Diablo with your usual Rogue/Archer/Warrior/Healer/Wizard, but the face value of this is the only thing it has in common with Diablo, underneath that face is a very deep layer of meat that you can sink your teeth into, criss-crossing classes to bring out powerful hybrids with their own distinct class names, with a community mod that adds even more class variations, i've only played as a magic user thus far and have found it to work responsively and easy to my control.

The moves can sometimes be very flashy and over-powered making the monsters into mush with the right set of gear, but playing with my co-op partner I noticed for the first half of the game as a tank he struggled to stay alive cause the monsters provided a serious challenge to him whilst he was under equipped.

It's addictive game play is a staple for why people still play the game to this very day, with a semi-private but active none the less multiplayer server list of people going through the entire story together.

So with all this being said, I give it an exceptional 8 based on high replay value and addicting return value.


Story Telling:  This is a tricky area, I know the premise of the game is very much based on old Greek mythos with characters like Zeus, Leonidas, and the like all being in the game, but unless you sit there and read every text dialogue that these characters use you'll never fully understand what's going on anyway.

The game is extremely long with what some 14 hours into the game and only being on the second region, we still have an extremely long way to venture and so much more to learn about this universe, but again with the original point the story telling seems to be spread out dramatically from one area to the next and mostly told through fetch this/kill that type of quests, meaning you're less likely to pay attention to what people have to say and therefore focus more on gameplay than anything story related.

For that I give this area of the game a 6, the positive side would be the long story of man vs creature a lot of which we've read about or watched movies on growing up, the down side will be that most of the player base will skip over the arching-story just to get to the next set of monster fodder for their loot grabs.

Customization:  I was tempted to label this section of the review as just 'Loot' because there is a lot of it, thousands of different pieces that can make your character look snazzy, or rough to set you apart from the rest of the group, weapons are diverse and act diverse based on the type that you wear, each piece ranging from an array of different rarity colors can boast a powerful set of buffs that can turn the side of battle by mixing and matching them.

Unfortunately this is also a problem, there is no cosmetic only option and this can leave you looking quite silly if one piece has better buffs than another and you decide that stats are better than fashion, currently my guy rocks what looks like a mini-skirt and a Princess Tiara all in the sake of a faster mana regen, where as my co-op partner is decked out in a cool warrior outfit because he got lucky enough to find fashionable armor that gave great stats.

Coloring dye is present in the game, alebit useless cause you can only dye the color of your base tunic, I haven't checked to see if there was a mod to change this but if it doesn't exist yet (it'd be nice to have it in the future!) There also isn't any customization in the way your character can look when starting him out other than choosing male or female as your gender.

So for this area I give it an 8, key factors being a diverse array of weapons/armors and the weapons actually acting different in terms of colored effects, negative factors that keep it from being a 9-10 are dyes that are completely useless, creation of a character has literally no customization option leaving everyone looking the same when first starting out, and a cosmetic only option missing from the game so we don't have to look silly to be effective.

Overall:  I love this game thus far, if they came out with a new one i'd buy it immediately, the series has been what Diablo 3 should've been the entire time, i'm not going to give the overall a final score cause I want you the readers to make your own opinions and decisions after playing it, my review is simply my experience thus far with the game and i'm confident in saying that i'll be a regular part of this community for as long it survives, it has a very addictive nature and it keeps me entertained the entire time.

We're in the business of entertainment so i'd say it's a worth while pick even at a full price, thanks for reading guys!

Titan Quest is a Diablo-esque game where you point and click to kill enemies, with a more Roman look to it. It plays out pretty much the same, although you don't pick a class at the very start. When you first level up is where everything begins: you pick your class and you build it up instead of having presets. The interesting part afterwards is that you get to chose a second class some levels afterwards in order for your character to be more unique. You could, for example build a fire Mage with Warrior skills too. You have 3 difficulty settings that you unlock throughout your playthroughs, and you get to keep your weapons and items, but you lose some resistances, so building those up from the start is a must. You also get relics from defeated enemies that you can use on your items to boost your equipment, which is very similar to what Diablo has with Gems.\n\nI recommend this game to anyone who loves Diablo-type games. Titan Quest: Immortal Throne is an expansion to the 2006 action RPG Titan Quest developed by Iron Lore Entertainment. Immortal Throne is a single player and multiplayer game taking place in a fantasy world based on Greek / Egyptian / Oriental mythology.

If you are thinking of getting this game, make sure you get the Gold Edition, which includes both Titan Quest and Immortal Throne. Remember to install both games, but launch Immortal Throne only as it includes the original Titan Quest story campaign with lots of gameplay improvements. You will need the original Titan Quest in order to get Immortal Throne to work.

For a game released in 2006, im surprised that the graphics still hold out quite well in 2013. The environment art in particular still looks lush and crisp and doesn't lose out to the more recently released Diablo 3. I especially liked how there are no loading screen when i transition from the overworld to a cave / dungeon. It just looked very smooth and natural. Character customization options are very limited however, and you can only choose your gender and the colour of your tunic. More options to change hairstyles or skin colour would have been very welcome here.

The main story campaign is rather lengthy and it took me about 30 hours to finish all 4 story acts and that is considering I had skipped some side quests. There are harder difficulties to unlock and if you are dedicated enough, it can easily go up to 100s of hours.

Gameplay wise, being an Action RPG, it follows closely to the standard hack and slash action RPG style pioneered by the Diablo series. Unlike Diablo however, it has 9 different unique skill trees each with its own flavour, and you can mix and match any 2 of them that complements your playstyle. Wanna play a full on brutish warrior tank? A pure glass cannon caster? A hybrid of both? A necromancer rogue? You make the choice. There are alot of combinations of playstyle available.

Music is competently done, and sounds appropriate when played in the respective areas, gives the game world a little more flavour. Sound effects are also appropriately meaty with every swoosh of a blade and blast of a magic spell. Voice over work for the NPCs are a little forced and overacted but nothing too jarring.

Now as for the downsides, the backstory of the game is unremarkable and boring. I never really paid attention to the story and quest givers as it just feels like another excuse to get you kill more mobs. Early game can also feel abit tedious when you keep seeing the same mobs over and over again. It does get better at the later acts, where you get to see more interesting mob varieties.

The game can be very grindy and I felt that character progression can be abit too slow at times. Because this game released back in 2006, it lacks the bells and whistles of modern Action RPGs, such as needing to manually pick up gold, do item tetris in your inventory, and no hirelings to help sell items.

There is a Co-op mode, but unfortunately it didn't work well at all when I tried to co-op with a friend, as we encountered bugs when trying to synch up our questlines. It sometimes doesn't even recognize that we have completed the quest. Do not get this game if you are thinking of co-op. There are some temporary solutions available, but we figured it wasn't worth the hassle and would be complete wasted trip if the game decides to screw up at the later acts if we continue to co-op.

Overall Rating: 7.0 / 10

The interesting part afterwards is that you get to chose a second class some levels afterwards in order for your character to be more unique. You could, for example build a fire Mage with Warrior skills too. You have 3 difficulty settings that you unlock throughout your playthroughs, and you get to keep your weapons and items, but you lose some resistances, so building those up from the start is a must. You also get relics from defeated enemies that you can use on your items to boost your equipment, which is very similar to what Diablo has with Gems.\n\nI recommend this game to anyone who loves Diablo-type games.
